Award.AwardTitle: Canonical metrics on four dimensional varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
The two main themes of the research proposed focus on the study of the moduli spaces of Einstein metrics and constant scalar curvature Kahler metrics at a point on the boundary of the classifying space. The first part of the proposal is a natural development of the PI's previous work, and plans to generalize aspects of Seiberg-Witten Theory, estimates on Riemannian curvatures, and obstructions to the existence of Einstein metrics on 4-orbifolds. Further implications of obstructions to the existence of Einstein metrics on smooth manifolds are expected. The other part the proposal addresses the study of Kahler structures. The project proposed on the classification of Ricci flat asymptotically locally euclidean Kahler manifolds (non-hyperkahler) establishes a starting point in the study of the compactification of the moduli space of constant scalar curvature Kahler manifolds. The specific tools used come from twistor spaces, geometric analysis, algebraic geometric stability, and Seiberg-Witten theory.

In spite of the tremendous developments over the last twenty years, there is still a lot that eludes us about the geometry of manifolds in low dimensions. The proposed research aims to develop interactions between different geometric structures such as Riemannian geometry, differential topology and Kahler geometry on four dimensional spaces. The PI plans to approach classification problems of special geometries (ALE Ricci flat Kahler), and also to understand existence and non-existence of Einstein or constant scalar curvature Kahler geometric structures on 4-manifolds, or 4-manifolds with singularities. These topics are of great importance not only in differential and algebraic geometry, but also in mathematical physics (string theory).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI’s research focuses on the interactions between different areas of geometry, such as differential geometry, symplectic topology, Kahler geometry and algebraic geometry. These areas and the techniques used in understanding them are quite different. Many of the problems and the tools involved in their study come from mathematical physics: string theory, general relativity, or classical mechanics. 

 

One of the PI’s projects concerns the understanding of spaces which asymptotically look like quotients of the Euclidean 4-space. In particular, the PI proved the classification of the ALE Ricci-flat Kahler surfaces, generalizing the classification of gravitational instantons due to Kronheimer. The insight in this classification is the correspondence between ALE Ricci-flat Kahler manifolds and a special class quotient singularities. The dictionary which relates the two areas of Kahler geometry and notions of deformations and stability in algebraic geometry has been actively developed in the recent years. We expect to have a deeper understanding of these relations in the near future. Furthermore, the PI showed the relation between the explicit constructions of metrics due to Eguchi-Hanson, Gibbons-Hawking, Hitchin and Kronkeimer, and an analytical construction of Tian-Yau. This answered a question posed by Yau in his plenary lecture at the 1978 International Congress of Mathematicians.

Other projects which were finalized by the PI during this award concern the computation of a differential invariant called the Yamabe invariant on a class of symplectic 4-manifolds. This computation sheds new light on the relation between smooth manifolds and spaces with singularities. In a different direction the PI considered manifolds endowed with a complex structure and a compatible metric called balanced. The PI proved a characterization result of Moishezon manifolds with positive total scalar curvature. 

 

During the period of this award the PI gave numerous talks at conferences and seminars in the United States and abroad (Canada, France, Romania, Israel). She was the main organizer of two workshops at Vanderbilt University. Young researchers and members of under-representative groups were given the opportunity to speak in the workshops, or just financial support to attend them.

The PI is also one of the main organizers of a weekly Geometry Seminar at Vanderbilt University. She sponsored several speakers to visit the Math Department and give talks in the Coloquium or the Geometry Seminar.
